Eyewitnesses reported remarkable phenomena‚Äîspeaking in tongues, visions, and what some described as visible flames resting on people during prayer.

facebook.text:
What would you fight for over 40 years?

William Wilberforce was elected to the British Parliament at just 21 years old. At 26, he experienced a profound evangelical conversion.

He could have had a comfortable political career. Instead, he chose to fight the most powerful economic interests of his day: the slave trade.

In 1787, he introduced his first bill to abolish the slave trade. It was defeated.

He tried again in 1788. Defeated.
1789. Defeated.
1791. Defeated.

Year after year, he faced opposition from wealthy merchants, political allies, and even threats to his life.

Finally, in 1807‚Äî20 years after he began‚Äîthe slave trade was abolished in Britain.

But Wilberforce wasn't done. Slavery itself still existed.

He kept fighting for 26 more years.

In 1833, just three days before his death, he learned that the bill to abolish slavery throughout the British Empire would pass.

Some causes are worth a lifetime of persistence.

linkedin.text:
William Wilberforce spent 46 years pursuing a single goal.

Elected to Parliament at 21, he was well-positioned for a conventional political career. Instead, at 26, he committed to ending the slave trade‚Äîdirectly opposing the economic interests that funded many of his colleagues.

From 1787 to 1807 (20 years), he introduced abolition legislation repeatedly. Each time, it failed.

In 1807, the slave trade was finally abolished.

But his work wasn't done. For 26 more years, he fought to abolish slavery itself.

In 1833, three days before his death, he learned the Slavery Abolition Act would pass.

Leadership lessons from Wilberforce:

‚Ä¢ Clarity of purpose sustained decades of effort
‚Ä¢ He built coalitions (the "Clapham Sect")
‚Ä¢ He used multiple strategies: legislation, public education, consumer boycotts
‚Ä¢ He measured success in generations, not quarters

Some missions require thinking in decades.

What's worth that kind of commitment?

#Leadership #Purpose #LongTermThinking #Persistence

What happens when students catch a vision?

In July 1886, evangelist D.L. Moody gathered 251 students from 89 colleges for a month-long Bible study conference at Mount Hermon School in Massachusetts.

Nobody expected what would happen next.

By the conference's end, 100 students had committed to become foreign missionaries.

They became known as "The Mount Hermon 100."

Two of those students‚ÄîRobert Wilder and John Forman‚Äîspent the next year touring 167 college campuses. 2,200 more students committed to missions.

They formed the Student Volunteer Movement with a bold watchword: "The evangelization of the world in this generation."

The results over the following decades:
‚Ä¢ 6,200 student volunteers by 1888
‚Ä¢ Over 20,500 missionaries reached the field
‚Ä¢ Similar movements spread to Britain, Scandinavia, and South Africa
‚Ä¢ John R. Mott, a key leader, later received the Nobel Peace Prize

One conference. 100 students. Generational, global impact.

linkedin.text:
In 1886, a conference of 251 students produced 100 who committed to a common mission.

They called themselves "The Mount Hermon 100."

Two of them spent the following year visiting 167 institutions, recruiting 2,200 more to the cause.

The organization they founded‚Äîthe Student Volunteer Movement‚Äîeventually deployed 20,500 people to their mission field.

Their recruitment strategy was simple but effective:
‚Ä¢ Clear, compelling vision ("The evangelization of the world in this generation")
‚Ä¢ Peer-to-peer mobilization
‚Ä¢ Campus-by-campus organizing
‚Ä¢ Regular large gatherings to maintain momentum

Their peak convention in 1920 drew nearly 7,000 attendees.

One leader, John R. Mott, went on to receive the Nobel Peace Prize.

The lesson: A clear mission, activated through peer networks, can scale beyond what traditional institutions achieve.

What mission could mobilize your generation?

The Great Pyongyang Revival

On this night, 1,500 people gathered at Central Presbyterian Church in Pyongyang, Korea, for a prayer service.

When Elder Kil Sun-ju stood and publicly confessed his sins, something shifted in the room.

Suddenly, hundreds began praying out loud simultaneously. An eyewitness described it:

"The sound was like the falling of many waters, an ocean of prayer beating against God's throne."

People wept. People confessed. Enemies reconciled.

Within two months, 2,000 had become Christians. By mid-1907, the number reached 30,000. Pyongyang became known as "the Jerusalem of the East."

The revival established practices that continue in Korean churches today: dawn prayer meetings, simultaneous audible prayer, and strong Bible study emphasis.

118 years later, South Korea sends the second-most missionaries in the world‚Äîall tracing back to what began on this night.

What emerged was described as "an ocean of prayer beating against God's throne."

The organizational results:
‚Ä¢ 2,000 new participants within two months
‚Ä¢ 30,000 by mid-year
‚Ä¢ Establishment of cultural practices (dawn meetings, group prayer) that persist 118 years later

Today, South Korea sends the second-most missionaries globally and has one of the world's highest church attendance rates.

The catalyst wasn't a program or strategy‚Äîit was a leader willing to be vulnerable first.

Vulnerability at the top often unlocks transformation throughout an organization.

facebook.text:
üìÖ ON THIS DAY: May 24, 1738

John Wesley's "Aldersgate Experience"

On this evening, John Wesley reluctantly attended a small religious meeting on Aldersgate Street in London.

Wesley was already 35 years old. He had been an ordained minister for 13 years. He had traveled across the Atlantic as a missionary to Georgia. He had practiced strict spiritual disciplines his entire life.

But by his own admission, something was missing.

That night, while someone read aloud from Martin Luther's preface to the book of Romans, something shifted.

Wesley later wrote:

"About a quarter before nine, while he was describing the change which God works in the heart through faith in Christ, I felt my heart strangely warmed. I felt I did trust in Christ, Christ alone, for salvation; and an assurance was given me that He had taken away my sins, even mine, and saved me from the law of sin and death."

This "heart strangely warmed" moment transformed Wesley's ministry.

Over the next 50+ years, he would travel 250,000 miles, preach 40,000 sermons, and start a movement that today includes over 80 million people worldwide.

From one warmed heart to a world on fire.

"I felt my heart strangely warmed. I felt I did trust in Christ, Christ alone."

The shift from external compliance to internal conviction transformed his effectiveness.

Over the following 50 years:
‚Ä¢ 250,000 miles traveled
‚Ä¢ 40,000 presentations delivered
‚Ä¢ Organizational infrastructure built (the "class meeting" system)
‚Ä¢ Movement of 80+ million traced to his work

The leadership insight: External credentials can't substitute for genuine conviction.

Authenticity unlocks impact in ways credentials alone cannot.

#Leadership #Authenticity #Impact
